related_items.title: Constantinople, Smyrna, Beyrout, Ba'albec, Damascus
description: 1 album (86 albumen photoprints) ; 36 x 46 cm. (album) | General views of Istanbul, Izmir, Beirut, Damascus, Jaffa and Ramlah. Includes mosques, churches, tombs, cemeteries, city walls, gates, columns, bridges, waterfronts and obelisks.  Archaeological sites including Roman temples and the Great Court in Baʻlabakk. Two photos of Turkish fire fighters and three portraits including a Chaldean man, a Circassian man and a woman.

related_items.title: Mosques in Istanbul and archaeological sites in Bergama, Turkey and Egypt
description: 138 photographic prints : albumen ; 29 x 37 cm. or smaller. | Predominately photographs of mosques in Istanbul, especially the Kariye Camii (Church of St. Saviour in Chora) and Ayasofya Camii (Hagia Sofia). Other mosques included are the Sultanahmet Camii, the Sulemaniye Camii, Rüstem Paşa Camii, Ayazma Camii, Sokollu Mehmed Paşa Camii, Şehzade Camii, Hamidiye Camii, Laleli Camii, Fatih Camii, Nuruosmaniye Camii, Yeni Camii  Nusretiye Camii, Bodrum Camii, Büyük Mecidiye Camii, and Kiliç Ali Paşa Camii,  Kücük Ayasofya Camii (Church of Saints Sergius and Bacchus), and Pertevniyal Valide Sultan Camii. Also depicted is the Saint Irene Church. Photographs of Bergama depict ruins and the town. A few photographs of Egypt by Pascal Sebah include an Arab cemetery and the Mosque of al-Burdayni in Cairo, and the ruins at the Temple of Sobek and Haroeris at Ombos. Portraits portray a Bedouin man, Mehmet VI and the daughter of Caliph Abdulmecid II.

related_items.title: Fotoĝrafla Türkiye : La Turquie en image = Turkey in pictures = Die Türkei im Bild.
description: [19] p., [154] leaves of plates : rotogravures ; 25 x 34 cm. | Reproductions of photographs showing the modernization of Turkey during the early Republic period and historic sites. Images include government buildings, banks, schools, museums, and monuments in Ankara; mosques, monuments, and views in Istanbul; landscape views in and near locations such as Bursa, Yalova, Giresun, Tortum, the Taurus Mountains, and the Çoruh river; archaeological sites in Bergama, Sardis, Urfa; the Istanbul Archaeological Museum and Hittite art; modern industrial facilities including ceramic works in Kütahya, coke factory in Zonguldak, locomotive repair shop in  Eskişehir, textile factory in Kayseri, and oil of roses establishment in Isparta; agricultural scenes including raisin drying in Izmir, sheep in Karaman, figs in Aydin, and cattle in Kars; sports and educational activities such as a sport festival in Ankara, women cooking and making clothing at the Ismet Pasha Girls' Institute, women and men in classes at the Commercial College of Ankara, and a lesson at the Normal School of Music in Ankara.

related_items.title: Stereograph views of Palestine, Lebanon, Syria, Turkey, and the Sinai
description: 248 photographic prints on stereo cards : stereograph, albumen ; 18 x 9 cm. | Photographs show general views of cities, towns, and villages; daily life and occupations in urban and agricultural settings; prominent monuments and landmarks; archaeological sites and ancient buildings; the landscape and the natural environment; and religious rites and processions in places in Palestine (present day Israel and the West Bank), Syria, Lebanon, Turkey, and the Sinai, Egypt. Locations in Palestine include  Ramleh (Ramlah), Jerusalem, Siloam, Nazareth, Bethany, Hebron,  Rām Allāh, Bethlehem, Jericho, Jaffa, Bethsaida, Samaria, Shechem (Nablus), Shumen (Sulam) and Mar Saba. Geographical features such as the Plain of Jericho, the Jordan and Dan Rivers, the Dead Sea, the Brook Cherith, the Valley of Merom and MountTabor, Mount Hermon, and the Mount of Temptation are also depicted. Damascus and Bāniyās in Syria, and Beirut and the ruins of Baʻlabakk in Lebanon are also shown. In Istanbul, mosques, fountains, streets, ruins and people are depicted in the neighborhoods of Galata, Ortaköy, and other places. The Monastery of St. Catherine and Mount Sinai are shown in the Sinai Penninsula.  Notable images include Holy Week ceremonies, the Nebi Musa procession, and the interior of a synagogue in Jerusalem; the "Jewish Quarter", Galata bridge, and street markets in Istanbul; the Greek Patriarch at Bethlehem and portraits of Russian and Abyssinian pilgrims, Arabs, Jews, Turks, Samaritans, Bedouins and others.

related_items.title: Imperial schools, architectural plans and student portraits, Ottoman Empire
description: 1 album (41 albumen prints) ; 32 x 40 cm. (album) | Photographs depict exterior views and architectural plans for military high and middle schools in Bursa, Kastamonu, Elazığ (Mamuretülaziz), Sivaş, Diyarbakır, Aleppo, and Beirut, and an imperial high school in Damascus. Includes group portraits of students from these schools.

The written permission of the copyright owners and/or holders of other rights (such as publicity and/or privacy rights) is required for distribution, reproduction, or other use of protected items beyond that allowed by fair use or other statutory exemptions. There may be content that is protected as "works for hire" (copyright held by the party that commissioned the original work) and/or under the copyright or neighboring-rights laws of other nations.  Responsibility for making an independent legal assessment of an item and securing any necessary permissions ultimately rests with persons desiring to use the item. See Legal Notices and Privacy and Publicity Rights for additional information and restrictions.

The Library of Congress would like to learn more about these materials and to hear from individuals or institutions having any additional information. Please contact us through our Ask A Librarian service.

Preferred Citation

Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information:
Frontline Diplomacy, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

Permissions

Items included in this collection with the permission of rights holders are listed below. For further use or reproduction of those items contact the rightsholders listed.

Interview of William W. Lehfeldt by William Burr, April 29, 1987, made available here with permission from The Foundation for Iranian Studies, 4343 Montgomery Avenue, Suite 200, Bethesda, MD 20814.

Interview of John S. Service by Rosemary Levinson, 1977, made available here with permission from The Regional Oral History Office, 486 The Bancroft Library, University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, California 94720-6000.

Oral history interviews conducted by Mrs. Ann Miller Morin (below), made available here with permission from Mrs. Ann Miller Morin, 3330 North Leisure World Blvd., Apt. 808, Silver Spring, MD 20906.

  • Interview of Anne Cox Chambers, October 23, 1985
  • Interview of Jane Abell Coon, November 4, 1986
  • Interview of Betty Crites Dillon, December 9, 1987
  • Interview of Ruth Lewis Farkas, October 24, 1985
  • Interview of Rosemary Lucas Ginn, October 28, 1997
  • Interview of Constance Ray Harvey, 1988
  • Interview of Mari-Luci Jaramillo, February 21, 1987
  • Interview of Jeane Jordan Kirkpatrick, May 28, 1987
  • Interview of Caroline Clendening Laise, May 8, 1985
  • Interview of Claire Boothe Luce, September 19, 1986               
  • Interview of Mary Seymour Olmsted, June 25, 1985
  • Interview of Nancy Ostrander, May 14, 1986
  • Interview of Rozanne L. Ridgway, March 18, 1987
  • Interview of Mabel Murphy Smythe, May 2, 1986
  • Interview of Margaret Joy Tibbetts, May 28, 1985
  • Interview of Melissa Foelsh Wells, March 27, 1984
  • Interview of Faith Ryan Whittlesey, December 7, 1988

These 17 interviews are part of the collection on deposit in the Sophia Smith Collection External.
